title: Pongal
short_description: Tamil Nadu's four-day harvest festival, thanksgiving to the Sun, nature, and cattle.
long_description:
Pongal is one of the most important festivals in Tamil Nadu, marking the start of the sun's six-month long journey northwards (Uttarayan). It is essentially a thanksgiving festival to nature—the Sun, the Earth, and the cattle—that help in the harvest. The word 'Pongal' means 'to boil over', symbolizing prosperity and abundance. The signature ritual involves cooking fresh rice with jaggery and milk in a new clay pot until it boils over, with the family shouting 'Pongalo Pongal!'.

Celebrated over four days, each day has a purpose. Bhogi Pongal is for discarding old belongings; Surya Pongal honors the Sun God; Mattu Pongal worships the cattle, where bulls are bathed, decorated, and honored (and sometimes engaged in the bull-taming sport Jallikattu); and Kaanum Pongal is for family reunions. The festival paints the state in vibrant kolams (floor designs), sugarcane stacks, and turmeric, offering a deep insight into the agrarian roots of Tamil culture.
significance: A harvest festival thanking the Sun God and farm animals for a bountiful yield.
key_rituals: Pongal Dish: Cooking the sweet rice dish in open courtyards.
Kolam: Drawing intricate patterns with rice powder outside homes.
Mattu Pongal: Decorating cows and bulls with bells, flowers, and paint.
Jallikattu: Traditional bull-taming sport held in villages.

faqs.q: What is the Pongal dish made of?
faqs.a: It is made of newly harvested rice, jaggery (cane sugar), ghee, and cashew nuts, cooked in milk.
